ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:

Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Emily Alcott

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Question 6: Instructor needs to be more careful about not being redundant, not telling the same stories over and over, etc.Question 3: Homework provided very little insight into the latest river research and did not engage students in meaningful discussions.Not sure where to put this comment but time and time again the instructors cut students off by speaking over them before they had finished asking their questions or providing a comment. What happened many times is that students specific questions were not answered and sometimes the students got frustrated and gave up trying to ask. I think the instructors need to listen more intently and not anticipate based on their years of experience. Besides not answering student questions cutting someone off or speaking over them is rude. I don't think that is the nature or intent of the professors but I do think listening is something they need to focus on next year.
jim is a much better teacher in the field than in the classroom. more field trips.Classes should follow basic vocabulary type lectures, field should flesh in the details and case studies.
See Question 13 below. This class should no longer be offered at Yale FES, or taught by a different professor.

Question 6 - I didn't answer this question because my issue with the class wasn't about the pace, it was about the content. I thought the material discussed in class was focused too much emphasis on the historical development of river classification systems and hydrological modeling methods. It wasn't too fast- or slow-paced, it was just repetitive.

The field trips were very valuable. The essays were pretty useful, but I wished that Jim would have given us a syllabus with a more clear set of assignments. It made the essays out of class seem last minute and not applicable. As if we were just being made to do extra work for the sake of doing extra work.

I'm glad I took the class. The instructor really shined when he took us out in the field. I learned a lot by his anecdotes. The course reader was a helpful supplement to the class. The text books, however, I cannot say, because they had sold out, so I never go to read them. I think going into the field and seeing the channels and classifying the channels then was the greatest help.I think the instructor assumes that we students have a working knowledge of the material. It would be helpful to explain the concepts for beginners and more in depth than cursory.
I just took this course to fill bin 1. It wasn't very useful.
Professional experience of the professor.
field trips
The field trips only because that is where the professor actually taught well.
Field trips, independent study
Our first field trip was useful in better understanding some of the concepts covered in class to date.

The field work with Jim MacBroom. He is an incredible professional with an impressive amount of knowledge and experience. He conveys his knowledge best when in the field.Also, the group projects in the second half of the semester were a great way to learn the practical applications of what we had discussed in class.
field trips
The field trips and the course project.
I appreciated that the instructor had real life experience, and he was very flexible and open to class input on scheduling and assignments. The final projects were fun and interesting.
-the field trips-hearing from the professor(s) about their real life experiences working in this field.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Homework papers are essentially a regurgitation of lecture and readings. I would much prefer synthesis and constructive problem solving than rehashing what has already been said. Very little new material (i.e. the latest in river thinking) was presented. The second instructor (Laura) although very knowledgeable did not add significantly to the class and took time away from possible student discussion. Also, I'm sorry but if you don't have a good speaking voice, you shouldn't be a lecturer at yale - at one point I saw a student with ear plugs in while she was lecturing.
keeping lectures basic and on topic

The in class lectures are disjointed. They overlap with one another and are unclear. There is no clear understanding of what we are supposed to learn from the class. It is not a linear trajectory of learning.
The required length of the out-of-class assignments is usually too long, which make them look like busy work.

This class was AWFUL. It failed to meet almost all of my expectations. The only thing I vaguely learned was how to classify rivers, but I learned more from the classification guide than I did the professor, so I wish I could get my money back for the class and just read the guide instead. **It should not be offered in the future.** I didn't learn anything I didn't know coming into the course, and it is the first rivers/hydrology class I've taken. So, I didn't learn anything in the class I didn't (a) think to generally be the case about how rivers function and how restoration should/shouldn't be done based on personal observation or (b) learn in a middle school science class. The professor basically gave us his opinion on the field for a semester, and the ridiculous final exam made me realize how very little we had learned. There were only a few assigned readings (historical journal articles) and then he told us that we had the option of reading basically a collection of notes that he had been putting together for 20 years. He left it at Audubon copy service, and those who were interested could go and copy this. Since I was taking other classes and figured he would have assigned reading if he thought it would be useful to our understanding, I didn't copy the notes/read them. Maybe I should have, but given how unedited his lectures were, I didn't look forward to trying to piece together 20 years of his notes. He thought it was funny/cute that all he had was notes rather than a book to assign, but felt that all the book were inadequate to what he wanted to teach. So, he chose to assign no textbook or other peer-reviewed readings (aside from those three or four journal articles at the start of the semester). I think this decision underscores the fact that he was basically teaching his opinion the entire time, rather than the established opinion of the field, which we could then evaluate after we had that basic understanding. Later, when we were doing our final project, he TOLD US what conclusions we should reach before we even went into the field, and then told us to put them in our paper and build up the body of the paper to support those (unfounded) conclusions. Pretty shocking instructions from a professor, given that this was supposedly a field science course.Speaking of the final project, our group turned in a draft of our final project on the Thursday of reading week, as the prof had asked us to do. On Monday of the following week I sent him an email on behalf of the group saying that we are looking forward to hearing his comments so that we could finish the project by the end of the week, and he just NEVER GOT BACK TO US. He never gave us comments on the project, or even responded to my email. So, our final project ended up being a rough draft. This is VERY disappointing considering how much work (papers, etc.) was involved in this class and how much time I put in.Also, the little act between Jim MacBroom and Laura (Lauren?) the woman who periodically sat in on the class from his firm was incredibly annoying and detracted from learning. She would constantly interrupt him for no reason at all just to tell him an inside joke or make fun of him. Again, it was unclear why she was in the class.

The content of the lectures, especially in the first half of the semester. Jim emphasized the history of river classification systems and hydrological modeling methods, wasting precious time on teaching us about old models which are no longer in use.
some orgainzation or big picture guidance about where we are going and what we should be learning...
Flow and relevance of the lectures. Slide printouts were not always helpful, often unreadable.

The workload was pretty heavy compared to other classes, which i didn't expect. Plus, the assignments just felt like busy work - there wasn't much feedback from the TA, and I don't think the prof looked at anything. Also, it was a bit much to require a final exam, group paper, AND group presentation.

-the feedback on the written assignments was not very clear.-also for some of the written assignments, it seemed that the purpose of the assignment was to provide a chance for creative problem solving, but I felt inadequately prepared to provide genuinely creative solutions. Talking with other students about this assignment, we felt that the assignments were set up in a way that they really only had one answer. I'm sure there are more answers, but it would have been useful to have more options presented before the assignments, or perhaps a presentation on how to research these options.-the software for the equations was not available on the FES computers and it was not compatible with students' mac computers. Also, the equation section was never clearly explained. It was just thrown out there, most of the students didn't really seem to get it, and then the equations were just forgotten about. I would have liked to come away from the class with a better understanding of how to use and apply these equations.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Instructor was always very willing to go the extra mile to help students. The TA was largely absent from the course, literally - not being in class, not adding to the in class content (which would have been nice to have some other perspectives), keeping the professor on track, etc. also we received no feedback about our homework papers and didn't receive our mid-term until the last day of class (professors fault I think).
very good availability of both
Good.
TA was fine

Jim was very helpful in answering questions before and after class, and in the field. He was not very timely in his responses to email questions.Emily was responsive when I emailed her, but I didn't really go to her for much help.
The TA was great. She was always available and made sure that any confusion or disorganization in the rest of the course was clear to the students. Jim was also helpful.
Instructor does not respond to e-mail.Emily was most helpful with a difficult homework assignment. She provides clear explanations and is patient. Flexible meeting times.
Emily Alcott and Jim were both very responsive and flexible.
The TA was very available. The professor was also very available, especially for extra field work. The professor was difficult to contact outside of class and planned field trips, though.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am interested in development and restoration issues and this course pertains to both.
understanding river function and options for restoration
It is a bin.

This course, as billed, would have been important to my future work in land restoration and management. It was therefore a total disappointment. I regret taking the class. It was really a waste of the precious time I have at FES. I wish FES did a better/more strict job of screening professors and courses, because this was really unacceptable.
It is extremely important to my course of study which incorporates water management. My coursework would be missing something if I had not taken this course.

This course does not fit into my program. But none of the other Bin 1 requirements looked interesting or fitting either, so I thought this class might at least be fun (a few of our field trips were fun!).

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Student and faculty advice. Instructors excellent reputation.
It is a bin requirement.
To learn how rivers work and how activities upstream may influence downstream coastal ecosystems.

See above. I have had a long-standing interest in river form and function and thought this would be a great class to take. I was also looking to the field work. The first field trip was fine, but we had a later one where we basically stood outside on a sidewalk and listened to a lecture. Unclear why the field trip was necessary.
I am very interested in river systems and how to restore them to their natural condition. I was thrilled to be able to take a class with someone as experienced and well-respected as Jim MacBroom.
I wanted to learn how to identify river channels and I wanted to participate in field trips and outdoor labs.
Bin 1
I wanted to find out if I would be interested in pursuing more work in ecological restoration and also take a course where I would get a chance to work in the field.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
not quite i wanted to see more examples of restoration techniques
no
NO! See answers above. This class was an embarrassment to FES.

In many ways, yes, the class lived up to my expectations. I was happy to learn about the Rosgen classification system, hydraulic modeling, and regime theory. I valued hearing about various projects which Jim has worked on, and I loved the group project and field trips. Unfortunately, I felt that about 50% of the lectures did not live up to my expectations as they felt repetitive and irrelevant.
It met my expectations

For the most part. Some of the readings and assignments were a little disappointing, but the professor's real life experiences about working in this field and the class field trips ans field work were very valuable.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
i better understand rivers yes
No, and that's not good because I didn't expect much.
Yes.
SEE ABOVE
See above.
I have a better understanding of river processes and restoration.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: i enjoyed trhe group process and learned alot from other people
Advantages were that I learned from the other students.
My group worked very well together.

The prof allowed there to be SIX people in our final project group, way more than could function optimally (or even vaguely efficiently). Of course he only had three projects to choose from for the entire class, so he should have seen thiscoming.

The group work was the highlight of the class. I learned a lot by applying the principles discussed in class to an actual case study in the local area. I appreciated the chance to do field work with Jim and his colleague Laura Wildman. I am very proud of our group's final product. I could never have produced a paper of such quality on my own during the same period of time.
I enjoyed working with other students and collaborating and thinking through problems together. I was frustrated that some students were not as engaged and consequently brought down group morale.
I was able to learn to a greater degree certain aspects of river processes and restoration. Both my partner and I felt free to use our creativity.
This was the best group project I've ever been a part of. We all devoted the necessary time to it, took a piece of the final project and all came together to efficiently compile.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This is an excellent course with potential for practical applications. The professor is highly experienced in the field (seems rare at yale) as well as being a researcher and pushing the science into new areas.
Only only only take this course if you are positive you are interested in river restoration.
Do the readings to get more out of the class.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE!
Go to all the field trips. Develop a relationship with Jim. Pick a group project you are passionate about.
go on the field trips
Make good use of the course reader. Ask lots of questions.
This class seems to be a fun alternative to some of the other Bin 1 options because you get a practioner's point of view and get outside. It sort of helps you think about materials flows.
